content_pillars.name: Nutrition & Healthy Eating
content_pillars.description: MOH dietary guidelines, macronutrient education, Malaysian food myths, nutrition data, and evidence-based healthy eating advice for Malaysian consumers
content_pillars.target_audience: Health-curious Malaysians who want to understand nutrition better — from gym beginners to experienced fitness enthusiasts looking for science-backed info
example_topics: How much protein do Malaysians actually need per day? (MOH guidelines vs gym bro science)
Malaysian Dietary Guidelines 2024 explained: What Suku Suku Separuh really means for your plate
Calories in your favourite mamak dishes — and healthier swaps you'll actually enjoy
The truth about 'zero sugar' labels in Malaysia: What FSQD regulations actually require
Why Malaysian obesity rates hit 54.4% — and what the NHMS data tells us about our diet
Complete guide to reading nutrition labels on Malaysian food products
Protein myths busted: Do you really need a protein shake after every workout?
How hormones and antibiotics in chicken affect your health — what the science says
content_pillars.typical_cta: Now that you know your daily protein needs, the hard part is actually hitting them consistently. Diet Chicken meals have exact macros on every pack — so you always know what you're getting, no calorie-counting app needed.

content_pillars.name: Meal Prep & Fitness Lifestyle
content_pillars.description: Practical meal planning for Malaysian fitness enthusiasts and busy professionals — weekly meal prep guides, gym nutrition, cost comparisons vs eating out, and protein goal strategies
content_pillars.target_audience: Busy Malaysian professionals and gym-goers who struggle to eat healthy consistently due to time constraints, and want practical meal prep solutions
example_topics: Weekly meal prep for Malaysian gym-goers: RM15/meal vs RM25 at healthy cafes
How to hit 150g protein daily on a Malaysian budget (without eating plain chicken breast)
The busy KL professional's guide to eating healthy when you work 10-hour days
Meal prep vs GrabFood: Real cost comparison for a week of healthy eating in Malaysia
Building muscle on Malaysian food: Complete bulking meal plan with local ingredients
Cutting season meal plan Malaysia: How to lose fat without giving up nasi lemak forever
5 high-protein Malaysian breakfast ideas that take less than 10 minutes
How to meal prep chicken breast 5 ways so you never get bored (Malaysian flavours edition)
content_pillars.typical_cta: If meal prep still feels like too much work on a Sunday night, Diet Chicken's ready-to-eat packs reheat in 3 minutes — same clean macros, zero cooking required.

content_pillars.name: Healthy Malaysian Living
content_pillars.description: Culturally relevant health content tied to Malaysian life — Ramadan nutrition, CNY healthy eating, hawker food survival guides, mamak alternatives, and festive season health tips
content_pillars.target_audience: All Malaysians who love local food culture but want to make healthier choices — especially during festive seasons, when eating out, and when navigating hawker stalls
example_topics: Ramadan nutrition guide: How to sahur and iftar without gaining weight
CNY reunion dinner survival guide: Enjoy the feast, keep your macros in check
Hawker food health guide: The best and worst choices at Malaysian food courts
The mamak survival guide: How to eat at mamak stalls without destroying your diet
Hari Raya cookie season: How many kuih raya is too many? (We did the math)
Healthy Deepavali: Traditional Indian sweets ranked by calories and sugar content
Is nasi lemak actually bad for you? The real nutrition breakdown might surprise you
How to order healthy at Malaysian chain restaurants (Secret Menu hacks)
content_pillars.typical_cta: Enjoying Malaysian food is part of who we are — but on the days you need a quick, clean meal between celebrations, Diet Chicken has your back with ready-to-eat options that taste like home cooking.

content_pillars.name: Food Quality & Transparency
content_pillars.description: Food label education, halal certification processes, hormone-free and antibiotic-free claims, FSQD regulations, and building consumer trust through food transparency
content_pillars.target_audience: Informed Malaysian consumers who care about what goes into their food — parents checking labels, fitness enthusiasts verifying protein claims, and health-conscious shoppers who want transparency
example_topics: How to read Malaysian food labels: What manufacturers don't want you to notice
Halal certification in Malaysia: What JAKIM's logo actually guarantees about your food
Hormone-free chicken in Malaysia: Marketing hype or real health benefit?
What 'no preservatives' really means under Malaysian food regulations
FSQD food safety standards: How Malaysia regulates your ready-to-eat meals
The truth about 'healthy' labels on Malaysian packaged food — KPDNHEP rules explained
Antibiotic-free poultry: Why it matters and how Malaysian farms are changing
Pineapple-fed chicken vs regular chicken: What the nutrition difference actually looks like
content_pillars.typical_cta: At Diet Chicken, we believe you deserve to know exactly what's in your food. Every pack shows full nutrition facts, and our chicken is pineapple-fed, hormone-free, and antibiotic-free — because transparency isn't optional.

target_business_sizes.primary: Middle-to-upper income Malaysian consumers (RM4,000-RM15,000/month household income)

requirements: Specific data (RM values, calorie counts, protein grams, Malaysian health statistics)
Named programs (MOH dietary guidelines, Suku Suku Separuh, NHMS data, JAKIM standards)
Audience focus (target specific consumer segments — gym-goers, busy professionals, meal preppers)
Actionable steps (exact meal plans, portion sizes, shopping lists, macros calculations)
Local context (Malaysian food comparisons, local ingredients, RM pricing, hawker stall references)
avoid: Generic health advice that could apply to any country
Tips without specific nutritional data or RM values
Vague 'eat healthy' suggestions without Malaysian food context
Content that shames Malaysian food culture or eating habits
Overly clinical or medical-sounding nutrition advice
